issue.title: Local Docker runs but see nothing
Local Docker runs but see nothing

content.raw:
We're working on more documentation for this, just some preliminary answers/clarifications here:

* After `docker run` you have your code running inside a docker "container". That is usually self-contained and separated from the rest of your machine, which is usually referred to as the "host".

* You can check that your container is up and running with `docker ps` on the host. On the output you can get your container's id.

* When the container is running, you can use the command `docker exec -it <container_id> bash` to move into the container. This feels similar to SSHing into a different computer, you have a separate file system in there and you can run commands such as `ps aux` to check what's running inside the container.

* It's normal that you don't see any traces of ROS topics outside the container. You should debug these things from within the container.

* The field computer's docker container is not spinning up the simulation, it just spins up the code which teams would load inside the real robot.

* Since this is your code running, it's up to you if you'll launch a window when running the container. Keep in mind that whatever you put in the docker file you provide will be running on AWS, not on your local computer.

* On the CloudSim setup, the simulator and the field computer run on separate containers, each container in a separate AWS instance with a different IP inside the VPN.

* `192.168.2.1` is the simulator's IP inside the VPN. The simulator will start a ROS master.

* `192.168.2.10` is the field computer's IP inside the VPN. The field computer should not start a ROS master, it should connect to the simulator's ROS master.
content.html:
We're working on more documentation for this, just some preliminary answers/clarifications here:

  • After docker run you have your code running inside a docker "container". That is usually self-contained and separated from the rest of your machine, which is usually referred to as the "host".

  • You can check that your container is up and running with docker ps on the host. On the output you can get your container's id.

  • When the container is running, you can use the command docker exec -it <container_id> bash to move into the container. This feels similar to SSHing into a different computer, you have a separate file system in there and you can run commands such as ps aux to check what's running inside the container.

  • It's normal that you don't see any traces of ROS topics outside the container. You should debug these things from within the container.

  • The field computer's docker container is not spinning up the simulation, it just spins up the code which teams would load inside the real robot.

  • Since this is your code running, it's up to you if you'll launch a window when running the container. Keep in mind that whatever you put in the docker file you provide will be running on AWS, not on your local computer.

  • On the CloudSim setup, the simulator and the field computer run on separate containers, each container in a separate AWS instance with a different IP inside the VPN.

  • 192.168.2.1 is the simulator's IP inside the VPN. The simulator will start a ROS master.

  • 192.168.2.10 is the field computer's IP inside the VPN. The field computer should not start a ROS master, it should connect to the simulator's ROS master.
